local_insights.title: Best Time to Visit Pashupatinath Temple
local_insights.content: Visit Pashupatinath Temple early morning (5-7 AM) to witness the morning aarti (prayer ceremony) and avoid crowds. The temple is most spiritual during Maha Shivaratri (February/March) when thousands of devotees gather. Local tip: Non-Hindus can observe from the east bank of Bagmati River - the view is actually better for photography.

local_insights.title: Thamel Money Exchange Secret
local_insights.content: Never exchange money at the airport or your hotel. Walk 5 minutes from Thamel to New Road area - exchange rates are 5-10% better. Look for shops with 'Money Exchange' signs, not banks. Always count money in front of the exchanger. Best rates are usually in the morning. Local secret: Ask for 'tourist rate' - they'll give you a better rate than what's displayed.

local_insights.title: Momo Eating Etiquette
local_insights.content: When eating momos in Nepal, locals never use a fork. Use your hands or chopsticks. The proper way: pick up the momo, dip in achar (spicy sauce), and eat in one bite. Don't cut it with a knife - it's considered disrespectful. Best momo places are tiny street stalls, not fancy restaurants. Look for places with long queues of locals - that's where the real momos are. Price: 150-300 NPR for a plate.

local_insights.title: Boudhanath Stupa Walking Direction
local_insights.content: Always walk clockwise around Boudhanath Stupa - it's a sacred practice. Walking counter-clockwise is considered disrespectful. The best time is early morning (6-8 AM) when locals do their kora (circumambulation). Join them - it's a beautiful spiritual experience. Don't take photos of people praying without permission. The stupa has 108 small Buddha images - locals believe walking around it brings good karma.

local_insights.title: Pokhara Lakeside Restaurant Secret
local_insights.content: The best Thakali food in Pokhara is NOT on Lakeside main street. Walk 10 minutes inland to find small family-run Thakali restaurants. Look for places with 'Thakali Kitchen' signs and locals eating there. The authentic Thakali set includes unlimited dal, bhat, tarkari, achar, and meat curry for 400-600 NPR. Avoid tourist restaurants on Lakeside - they charge 3x more for less authentic food.

local_insights.title: Sarangkot Sunrise Secret
local_insights.content: For Sarangkot sunrise, don't go to the main viewpoint with all the tourists. Ask locals for 'hidden viewpoint' - it's a 10-minute walk from the main area, completely free, and has better views. Leave Pokhara at 4:30 AM to reach by 5:30 AM. Bring warm clothes - it's freezing at dawn. Best months: October-November and March-April for clearest mountain views. Local tip: The tea shop owner knows the exact best spot - buy a tea and ask him.

local_insights.title: Trekking Guide Hiring Secret
local_insights.content: Never hire guides from Thamel or Lakeside tourist offices - they charge 3x more. Go directly to the trekking starting point (like Nayapul for Annapurna) and hire local guides there. Local guides charge 2000-3000 NPR per day vs 5000-8000 from agencies. They know the trails better and support local economy. Always negotiate price before starting. Good guides will show you hidden viewpoints and local teahouses.

local_insights.title: Dang Tharu Festival Timing
local_insights.content: The best time to visit Dang is during Maghi (January 14-15) - the biggest Tharu festival. The entire district comes alive with traditional dances, music, and feasts. Locals wear traditional Tharu dress and perform Deuda dance. You can join the celebrations - Tharu people are very welcoming. Book homestays in advance during this time. The festival celebrates the Tharu New Year and harvest season.

local_insights.title: Kailali Banana Season
local_insights.content: Kailali is famous for bananas, but the best time to try authentic banana dishes is during harvest season (September-December). Visit Tikapur's local markets early morning to see farmers selling fresh bananas. Try banana momo, banana chips, and banana wine - all unique to this region. The Banana Restaurant in Tikapur is famous, but the street vendors have more authentic versions. Local secret: Ask for 'kera ko achar' (banana pickle) - it's a local delicacy.

local_insights.title: Bargaining in Nepal Markets
local_insights.content: Bargaining is expected in Nepal, but do it respectfully. Start at 50-60% of the asking price. If they say 1000 NPR, offer 500-600. Smile and be friendly - it's a cultural exchange, not a battle. In tourist areas (Thamel, Lakeside), prices are inflated 3-5x. In local markets, prices are more fixed. Best bargaining: handicrafts, souvenirs, taxi rides. Don't bargain for food in restaurants - it's considered rude. Local tip: Learn to say 'thikai cha' (it's okay) and 'ali sasto' (a bit cheaper) in Nepali.

local_insights.title: Temple Entry Fees - Local Secret
local_insights.content: Many temples have separate fees for locals (50-100 NPR) and foreigners (500-1500 NPR). If you're with a local friend, sometimes you can enter with them at local rate. However, this money goes to temple maintenance - consider paying the foreigner rate to support preservation. Some temples (like Swayambhunath) have free entry for locals on certain days - ask around. The ticket is usually valid for the whole day - you can re-enter.

local_insights.title: Bhaktapur Juju Dhau Secret
local_insights.content: The famous 'Juju Dhau' (King Curd) in Bhaktapur is best from small shops in the old town, not the tourist stalls. Look for shops with clay pots (matka) - that's the authentic way. The curd should be thick, creamy, and slightly sweet. Best time to buy: early morning when it's fresh. Price: 50-100 NPR per pot. Local secret: The curd from shops near Nyatapola Temple is considered the best by locals.

local_insights.title: Monkey Temple - Safety Tips
local_insights.content: Swayambhunath (Monkey Temple) has aggressive monkeys. Keep bags zipped, don't carry food openly, and don't make eye contact with monkeys. If a monkey approaches, stay calm and walk away slowly. Don't run - they'll chase you. The monkeys are most active in the morning and evening. Best time to visit: midday when they're less active. Local tip: The monkeys respect the temple - they won't enter the main stupa area.

local_insights.title: Local Bus vs Tourist Bus
local_insights.content: Local buses in Nepal are an authentic experience but can be overwhelming. Tourist buses are comfortable but 5-10x more expensive. Local buses: 200-500 NPR, tourist buses: 2000-5000 NPR. Local buses are safe but crowded - you'll share space with chickens, vegetables, and locals. Tourist buses have AC and reserved seats. For short distances (Kathmandu to Bhaktapur), local bus is fine. For long distances (Kathmandu to Pokhara), tourist bus is worth it for comfort.

local_insights.title: Tipping Culture in Nepal
local_insights.content: Tipping is appreciated but not mandatory in Nepal. In restaurants, 10% is standard if service charge isn't included. For guides: 500-1000 NPR per day is generous. For porters: 300-500 NPR per day. In hotels, tip housekeeping 100-200 NPR. In taxis, round up the fare. Local tip: Tipping in small notes (10, 20, 50 NPR) is more appreciated than one large note - you can tip multiple people.

local_insights.title: Dang Tharu Homestay Experience
local_insights.content: The best way to experience Dang is through Tharu homestays. You'll sleep in traditional mud houses, eat authentic Tharu food, and learn about their culture. Homestays cost 1000-2000 NPR per night including meals. The hosts will teach you Tharu language, show you traditional farming, and perform cultural dances. Book through local tourism office or ask at Dharapani village. Best time: October-April when weather is pleasant.

local_insights.title: Kailali Dolphin Spotting Secret
local_insights.content: The Gangetic dolphins in Kailali's rivers are best spotted early morning (6-8 AM) or late afternoon (4-6 PM). The best spot is near Chisapani bridge on Karnali River. Hire a local boatman (500-1000 NPR) - they know where dolphins surface. Don't make loud noises - dolphins are sensitive. Best months: October-March when water is clear. Local tip: The dolphins are more active during full moon - locals believe they come closer to shore then.

local_insights.title: Pokhara Paragliding - Local Secret
local_insights.content: Paragliding in Pokhara is amazing, but book directly with operators, not through hotels. Hotels add 20-30% commission. Best operators are certified by APPI (Association of Paragliding Pilots). Price: 8000-12000 NPR for 20-30 minutes. Best time: October-November and March-April for stable weather. Local secret: Ask for 'cross-country flight' - it's longer and more exciting, but costs more. Always check weather - flights are cancelled if it's too windy.

local_insights.title: Kathmandu Street Food Safety
local_insights.content: Street food in Nepal is generally safe if you follow local wisdom. Eat where locals eat - if there's a queue, it's fresh. Avoid raw vegetables and unpeeled fruits. Stick to cooked foods: momos, samosas, chatpate. Look for vendors who handle money and food separately. Best street food areas: Asan Tole, Indra Chowk, New Road. Local tip: Your stomach needs 2-3 days to adjust - start with mild foods, gradually try spicier ones.

local_insights.title: Nepal SIM Card Secret
local_insights.content: Get a Nepal SIM card at the airport or in Thamel - it's cheap and essential. Ncell and Nepal Telecom are the main providers. Ncell has better coverage in cities, Nepal Telecom is better in mountains. Cost: 200-500 NPR for SIM + 500-1000 NPR for data package. You need passport and photo. Local secret: Buy data packages in advance for trekking areas - signal is weak but data works. Top up at any shop with 'Top Up' sign.
